posts.name:
Adam P. Boyd
Adam P. Boyd
posts.content:
I donâ€™t know who needs to hear this, but:

 The market decides the strategy. 

Let me give you a short story.

I trained a boutique P&C and health brokerage.

They had a very tight ideal client profile.

Only one problem: there are about 1,000 of these customers out there.

(And the market wasnâ€™t growing)

The company ran a 7 touch system (reaching out to a prospect 7 times to get a conversation and then a meeting).

It was great. For about 2 years.

Thenâ€¦.the reps were calling on the same people, again.

And, again.

 The approach to the market didnâ€™t fit the market.

So this firm adapted and moved to an account-based selling model.

(They went to a relationship-building plan to win customers)

They knew it would take 12-36 months to win most accounts, so they prioritized those they believed they had the best chance of winning, and put in place plans to get in with each CEO and/or CFO of those accounts.

Theyâ€™d still call some, but also visit in person, invite those people to events, and find other ways to engage.

They changed their approach based on the market.

The result? 20+% yoy growth...every year...
That's not the business porn you read about with 200% growth every year, but for most mortals, that's a great way to build wealth....

You know what Einstein says about compounding?

So my question to you isâ€¦ is your strategy based on the market?
Or on your preferences?

Thanks tofor the inspiration below.

comments.commentText:
Can't lie, Adam, you've got me thinking on this one... 

It's too easy to stick to our preferences or habits of doing things. Have to rethink from the client-side.
Great, now I want that mug!

posts.commentAdded: Great insights! Adapting to market dynamics is vital for sustained growth. Are your strategies aligned with customer needs? Lets discuss!

posts.name:
Daniel Epstein
Daniel Epstein
posts.content:
Looking for the perfect sales tactic? Stop.  

I thought: If I could just crack the code, everything would fall into place.

But hereâ€™s the truth no one tells you: there is no single secret. 

The biggest breakthroughs in sales donâ€™t come from some magical pitch or techniqueâ€”they come from combining a series of small skills, tweaks, and adjustments over time.

I learned this the hard way.

I used to chase the perfect script, the flawless objection handler, or the one-size-fits-all close. But it wasnâ€™t until I embraced the idea of never-ending improvement that my results transformed.

Every day, I focused on improving just 1%.
 A better opening question.
 Sharper listening skills.
 More thoughtful follow-ups. (but never say "follow up" to a client)

At first, the changes seemed too small to matter. But over time? They compounded in ways I couldnâ€™t have imagined.

If youâ€™re chasing a â€œmagic bulletâ€ to sales success, stop. Instead, ask yourself:
Whatâ€™s one small skill I can sharpen today?

Because the real secret to sales success isnâ€™t a tacticâ€”itâ€™s consistency, growth, and patience.

Whatâ€™s one small improvement youâ€™re working on today?

comments.commentText:
Experienced that! It is always about the small tweaks, and getting better at Psychology. 

Sales is a profession where emotional intelligence is not a plus. It is mandatory.
Well, I am trying to combine all you mentioned above into my strategy for coming months

Dana Strakova Glad to hear that! It's always the small tweaks - an airplane flying just 1 degree off heading between Los Angeles and New York can place an aircraft roughly 40 miles away from its destination.

posts.commentAdded: Great insights! Continuous improvement truly adds up. Today, Im focusing on enhancing my active listening skills. What about you?

posts.content:
AI Daily Brief â€“ January 22, 2025

Hereâ€™s whatâ€™s happening in the world of artificial intelligence today:

â€¢ President Donald Trump announced the Stargate AI project, pledging $500 billion to advance Americaâ€™s AI infrastructure. The initiative involves partnerships with OpenAI and Oracle, starting with a $100 billion AI data center in Texas. SoftBankâ€™s CEO also expanded their investment commitment to $500 billion.

â€¢ Following the Stargate AI initiative announcement, tech stocks surged. Oracleâ€™s stock rose 7%, reflecting investor optimism around the major AI investment.

â€¢ AI was a key topic at the World Economic Forum in Davos, with CEOs such as Elon Musk expressing confidence in AIâ€™s growth potential, particularly in startups.

â€¢ In Scotland, researchers are developing NeurEye, an AI tool that analyzes eye scans to detect early signs of dementia. With nearly a million scans collected, the goal is to identify patterns that could lead to earlier diagnosis and intervention.

â€¢ AI is being deployed to review CCTV footage in the Noah Donohoe case, using advanced algorithms to quickly flag human appearances for investigators.

What are your thoughts on these latest AI developments? Letâ€™s discuss below!

posts.name:
Luigi LENGUITO
Luigi LENGUITO
posts.content:
Day 2 
hashtag
#Davos... The reveal !


I think I'm starting to get the "Davos effect" - the serendipitous bumping in smart people that enrich you with new idea and perspectives. I have heard a lot of bad takes on Davos, I am not involved in the actual WEF scheduling (white badges) , so enjoying mostly side events and impromptu meetings, and I have to say the variety and experience of people is outstanding.

What did Day2 bring :

- Met Zak Brown, MacLaren CEO & F1 Team Principal
- Attendedevent on topics like Responsible AI, Cybersecurity for Critical Infrastructure, Threat Information Sharing , meeting a long series of experts CISOs and security experts - amazing community !
- Hacked my way in private parties at Santander and Semafor, fantastic connections and chats
- Bumped into, president of
- a mindshifting session on Disinformation/Misinformation- for me a real highlight as I learn how to express what
does for reputation !


Keep following for another day of
list items.

As you can see I'm not good with selfies, but I'm sure one of our best swag, thetie will become a classic ;)

Luigi LENGUITO I take your word! I will use it proudly

Managing and understanding large volumes of patient reviews has always been a significant challenge for healthcare providers. 

At RepuGen, we saw how overwhelming and time-consuming it was for practices to make sense of patient feedback, even though itâ€™s critical for improving care and building trust.

Thatâ€™s when we decided to create the AI Review Summary, a smart, innovative solution designed to turn detailed patient reviews into clear, actionable insights in just seconds. 

No more manually sifting through hundreds of reviews to understand what your patients are saying. This tool analyzes feedback for you, helping you quickly spot trends, uncover areas for improvement, and make informed decisions, all in a fraction of the time.

Our clients are already seeing the impact. By using the AI Review Summary, theyâ€™ve saved valuable time, improved service quality, and strengthened their reputation in an increasingly competitive healthcare market. 

Whether youâ€™re managing a small practice or a large organization, RepuGenâ€™s AI Review Summary is here to help you focus on what matters most-delivering exceptional care to your patients.

We built this solution because we believe great patient care starts with truly listening to your patients, and weâ€™re here to help you do that better, faster, and smarter.

Ready to see how it works? Letâ€™s connect!
